title: Care About Your Craft
advice: Why spend your life developing software unless you care about doing it well?

title: Think! About Your Work
advice: Turn off the autopilot and take control. Constantly critique and appraise your work.

title: You Have Agency
advice: It’s your life. Grab hold of it and make it what you want.

title: Provide Options, Don’t Make Lame Excuses
advice: Instead of excuses, provide options. Don’t say it can’t be done; explain what can be done.

title: Don’t Live with Broken Windows
advice: Fix bad designs, wrong decisions, and poor code when you see them.

title: Be a Catalyst for Change
advice: You can’t force change on people. Instead, show them how the future might be and help them participate in creating it.

title: Remember the Big Picture
advice: Don’t get so engrossed in the details that you forget to check what’s happening around you.

title: Make Quality a Requirements Issue
advice: Involve your users in determining the project’s real quality requirements.

title: Invest Regularly in Your Knowledge Portfolio
advice: Make learning a habit.

title: Critically Analyze What You Read and Hear
advice: Don’t be swayed by vendors, media hype, or dogma. Analyze information in terms of you and your project.

title: English is Just Another Programming Language
advice: Treat English as Just Another Programming Language. Write documents as you would write code: honor the DRY principle, ETC, automation, and so on.

title: It’s Both What You Say and the Way You Say It
advice: There’s no point in having great ideas if you don’t communicate them effectively.

title: Build Documentation In, Don’t Bolt It On
advice: Documentation created separately from code is less likely to be correct and up to date.

title: Good Design Is Easier to Change Than Bad Design
advice: A thing is well designed if it adapts to the people who use it. For code, that means it must adapt by changing.

title: DRY—Don't Repeat Yourself
advice: Every piece of knowledge must have a single, unambiguous, authoritative representation within a system.

title: Make It Easy to Reuse
advice: If it’s easy to reuse, people will. Create an environment that supports reuse.

title: Eliminate Effects Between Unrelated Things
advice: Design components that are self-contained, independent, and have a single, well-defined purpose.

title: There Are No Final Decisions
advice: No decision is cast in stone. Instead, consider each as being written in the sand at the beach, and plan for change.

title: Forgo Following Fads
advice: Neal Ford says, “Yesterday’s Best Practice Becomes Tomorrow’s Antipattern.” Choose architectures based on fundamentals, not fashion.

title: Use Tracer Bullets to Find the Target
advice: Tracer bullets let you home in on your target by trying things and seeing how close they land.

title: Prototype to Learn
advice: Prototyping is a learning experience. Its value lies not in the code you produce, but in the lessons you learn.

title: Program Close to the Problem Domain
advice: Design and code in the language of the problem domain.

title: Estimate to Avoid Surprises
advice: Estimate before you start. You’ll spot potential problems up front.

title: Iterate the Schedule with the Code
advice: Use experience you gain as you implement to refine the project time scales.

title: Keep Knowledge in Plain Text
advice: Plain text won’t become obsolete. It helps leverage your work and simplifies debugging and testing.

title: Use the Power of Command Shells
advice: Use the shell when graphical user interfaces don’t cut it.

title: Achieve Editor Fluency
advice: An editor is your most important tool. Know how to make it do what you need, quickly and accurately.

title: Always Use Version Control
advice: Version control is a time machine for your work; you can go back.

title: Fix the Problem, Not the Blame
advice: It doesn’t really matter whether the bug is your fault or someone else’s—it is still your problem, and it still needs to be fixed.

title: Don’t Panic
advice: This is true for galactic hitchhikers and for developers.

title: Failing Test Before Fixing Code
advice: Create a focussed test that reveals the bug before you try fixing it.

title: Read the Damn Error Message
advice: Most exceptions tell both what failed and where it failed. If you’re lucky you might even get parameter values.

title: “select” Isn't Broken
advice: It is rare to find a bug in the OS or the compiler, or even a third-party product or library. The bug is most likely in the application.

title: Don’t Assume It—Prove It
advice: Prove your assumptions in the actual environment—with real data and boundary conditions.

title: Learn a Text Manipulation Language
advice: You spend a large part of each day working with text. Why not have the computer do some of it for you?

title: You Can’t Write Perfect Software
advice: Software can’t be perfect. Protect your code and users from the inevitable errors.

title: Design with Contracts
advice: Use contracts to document and verify that code does no more and no less than it claims to do.

title: Crash Early
advice: A dead program normally does a lot less damage than a crippled one.

title: Use Assertions to Prevent the Impossible
advice: If it can’t happen, use assertions to ensure that it won’t. Assertions validate your assumptions. Use them to protect your code from an uncertain world.

title: Finish What You Start
advice: Where possible, the function or object that allocates a resource should be responsible for deallocating it.

title: Act Locally
advice: Keep the scope of mutable variables and open resources short and easily visible.

title: Take Small Steps—Always
advice: Small steps always; check the feedback; and adjust before proceeding.

title: Avoid Fortune-Telling
advice: Only look ahead as far as you can see.

title: Decoupled Code Is Easier to Change
advice: Coupling ties things together, so that it’s harder to change just one thing.

title: Tell, Don’t Ask
advice: Don’t get values from an object, transform them, and then stick them back. Make the object do the work.

title: Don’t Chain Method Calls
advice: Try not to have more than one dot when you access something.

title: Avoid Global Data
advice: It’s like adding an extra parameter to every method.

title: If It’s Important Enough To Be Global, Wrap It in an API
advice: …but only if you really, really want it to be global.

title: Programming Is About Code, But Programs Are About Data
advice: All programs transform data, converting an input into an output. Start designing using transformations.

title: Don’t Hoard State; Pass It Around
advice: Don’t hang on to data within a function or module. Take one down and pass it around.

title: Don't Pay Inheritance Tax
advice: Consider alternatives that better fit your needs, such as interfaces, delegation, or mixins

title: Prefer Interfaces to Express Polymorphism
advice: Interfaces make polymorphism explicit without the coupling introduced by inheritance.

title: Delegate to Services: Has-A Trumps Is-A
advice: Don’t inherit from services: contain them.

title: Use Mixins to Share Functionality
advice: Mixins add functionality to classes without the inheritance tax. Combine with interfaces for painless polymorphism.

title: Parameterize Your App Using External Configuration
advice: When code relies on values that may change after the application has gone live, keep those values external to the app. When you application will run in different environments, and potentially for different customers, keep the environment and customer specific values outside the app.

title: Analyze Workflow to Improve Concurrency
advice: Exploit concurrency in your user’s workflow.

title: Shared State Is Incorrect State
advice: Shared state opens a large can of worms that can often only be fixed by rebooting.

title: Random Failures Are Often Concurrency Issues
advice: Variations in timing and context can expose concurrency bugs, but in inconsistent and irreproducible ways.

title: Use Actors For Concurrency Without Shared State
advice: Use Actors to manage concurrent state without explicit synchronization.

title: Use Blackboards to Coordinate Workflow
advice: Use blackboards to coordinate disparate facts and agents, while maintaining independence and isolation among participants.

title: Listen to Your Inner Lizard
advice: When it feels like your code is pushing back, it’s really your subconscious trying to tell you something’s wrong.

title: Don’t Program by Coincidence
advice: Rely only on reliable things. Beware of accidental complexity, and don’t confuse a happy coincidence with a purposeful plan.

title: Estimate the Order of Your Algorithms
advice: Get a feel for how long things are likely to take before you write code.

title: Test Your Estimates
advice: Mathematical analysis of algorithms doesn’t tell you everything. Try timing your code in its target environment.

title: Refactor Early, Refactor Often
advice: Just as you might weed and rearrange a garden, rewrite, rework, and re-architect code when it needs it. Fix the root of the problem.

title: Testing Is Not About Finding Bugs
advice: A test is a perspective into your code, and gives you feedback about its design, api, and coupling.

title: A Test Is the First User of Your Code
advice: Use its feedback to guide what you do.

title: Build End-To-End, Not Top-Down or Bottom Up
advice: Build small pieces of end-to-end functionality, learning about the problem as you go.

title: Design to Test
advice: Start thinking about testing before you write a line of code.

title: Test Your Software, or Your Users Will
advice: Test ruthlessly. Don’t make your users find bugs for you.

title: Use Property-Based Tests to Validate Your Assumptions
advice: Property-based tests will try things you never thought to try, and exercise your code in ways is wasn’t meant to be used.

title: Keep It Simple and Minimize Attack Surfaces
advice: Complex code creates a breeding ground for bugs and opportunities for attackers to exploit.

title: Apply Security Patches Quickly
advice: Attackers deploy exploits as quick as they can, you have to be quicker.

title: Name Well; Rename When Needed
advice: Name to express your intent to readers, and rename as soon as that intent shifts.

title: No One Knows Exactly What They Want
advice: They might know a general direction, but they won’t know the twists and turns.

title: Programmers Help People Understand What They Want
advice: Software development is an act of co-creation between users and programmers.

title: Requirements Are Learned in a Feedback Loop
advice: Understanding requirements requires exploration and feedback, so the consequences of decisions can be used to refine the initial ideas.

title: Work with a User to Think Like a User
advice: It’s the best way to gain insight into how the system will really be used.

title: Policy Is Metadata
advice: Don’t hardcode policy into a system; instead express it as metadata used by the system.

title: Use a Project Glossary
advice: Create and maintain a single source of all the specific terms and vocabulary for a project.

title: Don’t Think Outside the Box—Find the Box
advice: When faced with an impossible problem, identify the real constraints. Ask yourself: “Does it have to be done this way? Does it have to be done at all?”

title: Don't Go into the Code Alone
advice: Programming can be difficult and demanding. Take a friend with you.

title: Agile Is Not a Noun; Agile Is How You Do Things
advice: Agile is an adjective: it’s how you do something.

title: Maintain Small Stable Teams
advice: Teams should be small and stable, where everyone trusts each other and depends on each other.

title: Schedule It to Make It Happen
advice: If you don’t schedule it, it’s not going to happen. Schedule reflection, experimentation, learning and skills improvement.

title: Organize Fully Functional Teams
advice: Organize Around Functionality, Not Job Functions. Don’t separate UI/UX designers from coders, frontend from backend, testers from data modelers, design from deployment. Build teams so you can build code end-to-end, incrementally and iteratively.

title: Do What Works, Not What’s Fashionable
advice: Don’t adopt a development method or technique just because other companies are doing it. Adopt what works for your team, in your context.

title: Deliver When Users Need It
advice: Don’t wait weeks or months to deliver just because your process demands it.

title: Use Version Control to Drive Builds, Tests, and Releases
advice: Use commits or pushes to trigger builds, tests, releases. Use a version control tag to deploy to production.

title: Test Early, Test Often, Test Automatically
advice: Tests that run with every build are much more effective than test plans that sit on a shelf.

title: Coding Ain’t Done ’Til All the Tests Run
advice: ’Nuff said.

title: Use Saboteurs to Test Your Testing
advice: Introduce bugs on purpose in a separate copy of the source to verify that testing will catch them.

title: Test State Coverage, Not Code Coverage
advice: Identify and test significant program states. Testing just lines of code isn’t enough.

title: Find Bugs Once
advice: Once a human tester finds a bug, it should be the last time a human tester finds that bug. Automatic tests should check for it from then on.

title: Don't Use Manual Procedures
advice: A computer will execute the same instructions, in the same order, time after time.

title: Delight Users, Don’t Just Deliver Code
advice: Develop solutions that produce business value for your users and delight them every day.

title: Sign Your Work
advice: Artisans of an earlier age were proud to sign their work. You should be, too.

title: First, Do No Harm
advice: Failure is inevitable. Make sure no one will suffer because of it.

title: Don’t Enable Scumbags
advice: Because you risk becoming one, too.

title: It’s Your Life. Share it. Celebrate it. Build it. AND HAVE FUN!
advice: Enjoy this amazing life we have, and do great things.
